moves.1. e4 e5 2. Qh5 Nf6 3. Qxe5+ Be7 4. Qb5: Here I like d3 better, as it pretty much pushes the knight to c5, where Be3 pushes it again, helping white develop.
moves.6... d5 7. Bf4 Bh4: Nxf2 is now a real threat.
moves.8... Bd7 9. Qxb7 Nc6 10. Bb5: gxh4?  Qxh4, Bg3 counters.  White nets a black bishop for a pawn.
moves.11. f3 Nf2 12. Kxf2 Nxd4: Now black is eyeing c2, giving it Ra1.  Here white should play Bd3 (and does).
moves.13. Bd3 Bc6 14. Qa6: The only square black didn't cover.
moves.14... Bd7 15. c3 Nc6: White is up four, it is a healthy lead.  But both rooks are buried.
moves.16. h4 Bc5+ 17. Be3 Bxe3+ 18. Kxe3 Nxe5: I like Kg2 better.  With Ke3 black gets to move a rook for free.
moves.22... Qe8+ 23. Kd4 Bf3 24. Rf1: When you threaten a piece, where will it move?  Here black can move Bg2, forking a knight and rook.
moves.24... Bg2 25. Re1: Oh no, Rg1 loses the knight, but Re1 sacrifices the rook.  Nothing is protecting it here.
